Often associated with Tenmangu shrines (fixture text).

A deity closely associated with agriculture, fertility, and prosperity, frequently linked to Inari worship. Uka-no-Mitama is venerated as a provider of abundant harvests and business success, and in many traditions is understood as one of the core identities behind Inari. Over centuries, local beliefs, syncretic practices, and regional folklore have shaped how this kami is perceived, sometimes merging attributes with other food and grain deities. This longer fixture text is intended to test extended content rendering, scrolling behavior, and layout stability in the CMS and mobile views.

folklore.title: The Lantern of Returning
folklore.story: A paper lantern once lit itself during a storm, guiding a lost child back to the shrine. Since then, visitors leave small lantern charms praying for safe returns.

folklore.title: The Fox’s Hidden Path
folklore.story: It is said a white fox appears on misty mornings, walking a path only the sincere can see. Following it supposedly leads to a small stone offering site behind the shrine.

citations.title: Kyoto City Official Travel Guide — Shrine & Temple Manners (visitor summary)
citations.author: Kyoto City / Kyoto Travel
citations.notes: Tourism-oriented etiquette summary; good for common-sense do/don’t guidance.

etiquette_topics.summary: How to enter respectfully: pause, bow lightly, and pass through calmly.
On the approach path, avoid the center line when possible and keep a relaxed, quiet pace.
Perform a simple hand-and-mouth rinse ritual before approaching the main hall (if the temizuya is available).
A common prayer style is: offering → bell (if present) → two bows → two claps → one bow.
Keep your voice low, don’t block pathways, and treat the space like a place of worship—not a theme park.
Photography rules vary. Follow signs, avoid photographing inside buildings unless allowed, and don’t disrupt rituals.
How to participate respectfully in common shrine activities: charms, fortunes, and wish plaques.

etiquette_steps.text: At the temizuya, take the ladle with your right hand and pour water over your left hand.
Switch: hold the ladle in your left hand and rinse your right hand.
Switch back to your right hand. Pour a little water into your left palm and rinse your mouth lightly (do not drink from the ladle).
Rinse your left hand again. Then tilt the ladle vertically so remaining water runs down the handle (a simple ‘clean finish’).
Return the ladle neatly. If the temizuya is closed or dry, simply proceed respectfully—many shrines modify practices at times.
Approach the haiden calmly. Stand behind the offering box line and wait your turn if there’s a queue.
Place a small offering into the saisen-bako (amount is personal—there’s no fixed rule).
If there is a bell, ring it gently once to signal your presence (don’t repeatedly ring it like an alarm).
Perform the common prayer form: bow twice, clap twice, then bow once.
During the quiet moment after clapping, you can offer a short prayer: gratitude first, then your request (keep it simple).
Step away to the side so the next person can approach. Don’t stand directly in front of the hall to review photos/messages.
Use an ‘inside voice’ throughout the grounds. Shrines are living religious spaces, not just tourist photo spots.
Don’t eat or smoke while walking around the main worship areas. If there are designated rest areas, use those.
Avoid touching sacred ropes, offerings, or ritual objects unless you’re clearly invited (some items are for priests only).
If a ceremony is happening, watch from a respectful distance and do not walk through the middle of the ritual space.
Omamori (charms) are typically carried with you (bag, wallet) rather than opened. Treat them as sacred items.
Ema (wish plaques): write a short wish or gratitude, then hang it in the designated ema area (not on random trees).
Omikuji (fortunes): read it, then either keep it or tie it at the shrine where indicated (ask or look for the tying area).
End-of-year/return etiquette: many people return old omamori to the shrine for appropriate disposal (often at a collection box).
